Role in Jerusalem Israeli diplomats are promoting the idea of United Nations control of the Temple Mount as a way to break the Israeli-Palestinian deadlock over the sacred site, the Israeli newspaper Haaretz said. Officials confirmed only that the foreign minister had discussed the idea with French and Egyptian leaders, noting that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, had not shown interest in the proposal.

U.S. Envoy to Israel Removed Ambassador Martin Indyk, an architect of Washington's policy in the Middle East, was relieved of his post and lost his security clearance pending an inquiry into whether he mishandled classified materials, State Department officials said. There was no suspicion of espionage.

France Allows Baghdad Flight France let a group fly from Paris to Baghdad, asserting that it never recognized an embargo on civilian air travel to Iraq. The flight, coming soon after two Russian flights to Baghdad, appeared intended to force the Security Council to reconsider its post-gulf war flight embargo.

Sect Leader Can Stay in U.S. A federal immigration court said Zhang Hongbao, leader of a banned Chinese meditation group who is under investigation on rape charges in Beijing, could stay in the United States for now, a rights group said, though he was not given asylum.

Court Clears Twins' Surgery England's Court of Appeal said doctors could proceed with an operation to separate joined twins that would sacrifice one to save the other. The parents' lawyers will appeal.
Yehuda Amichai The Israeli poet who distilled his experience -- and his nation's -- into highly metaphorical verse written in Hebrew and translated into more than 25 languages was 76.

Clinton Agrees to Put Oil Reserves on Market President Clinton ordered 30 million barrels of oil released from the nation's emergency reserve in the next month, a day after Vice President Al Gore injected the issue into the presidential campaign. Crude oil prices dropped and analysts said the move could help check the rise in fuel prices.

Mr. Gore held his first news conference in 67 days, defending his call for the oil release and vowing to ''confront friend and foe alike'' over the marketing of violent entertainment to children, despite the big donations he receives from Hollywood.

Gov. George W. Bush criticized the oil decision and told elderly voters that he would promote medical advances ''with new resources and new resolve'' by increasing financing for the National Institutes of Health and the National Cancer Institute.
Gore aides distributed news accounts from last year that they said showed Mr. Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney, then heading an energy-services company, praising OPEC for driving up oil prices.

E-Mail Reveals Fund-Raisers Reconstructed e-mail messages given to federal and Congressional investigators show that Mr. Gore's senior aides routinely characterized White House coffee sessions as fund-raising events in early 1996.
Attorney General Janet Reno said there was no basis for investigating Mr. Gore's relationship to donations from trial lawyers interested in a presidential veto.
NBC Opts for Baseball NBC said it would broadcast a baseball game instead of the first presidential debate, and might not show the third debate.
Review of Secrets Case Attorney General Janet Reno told President Clinton that she had ordered a review of prosecutors' handling of the case of the former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee.
Young Hacker Is Sentenced A 16-year-old from Miami, Jonathan James, was sentenced to six months in juvenile detention for penetrating government computers.

White House Releases List Of Clinton House Guests President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have had 404 overnight guests at the White House and Camp David since she began campaigning for the New York Senate seat in July 1999. The guests included campaign donors and Democratic fund-raisers. The White House and Mrs. Clinton's campaign denied any link between donations and sleepovers.
Negotiations to ban soft money in the Senate race collapsed after Mrs. Clinton offered a plan that Rick A. Lazio embraced -- until he learned that outside interest groups could help her but not him.

Interest Ebbs in Police Career Only about 1,300 recruits are expected to enter the Police Academy on Sept. 29, far fewer than the nearly 1,600 that officials had expected. Reasons for the shortfall are thought to include pay levels and a tarnished image of the Police Department.

Online Grocer Changes Plans Webvan said it was delaying plans to open facilities in Bergen County, N.J., and Maryland, and would not discuss a plan promoted by New York City officials on Thursday in which Webvan would take over a vacant South Bronx warehouse.
Princeton President Leaving Harold T. Shapiro, 65, said he would step down next year.
Union Leaders Plead Guilty Teachers in Buffalo ratified a five-year pact, and three union leaders pleaded guilty to contempt of court in connection with a walkout.
A Golden Partnership Gary Hall Jr. and Anthony Ervin, who train together, tied in the 50-meter freestyle. It was the second time that two gold medals were awarded for an Olympic swimming race.

Move to Shore Up Euro European, American and Japanese central banks, expressing concern over what they called a threat to the world economy, bought billions of euros, pushing the value to 90 cents, though it later slipped to 87.87.
Taco Shells Recalled Kraft said it was recalling Taco Bell brand taco shells because they contain a genetically engineered corn not approved for humans.
Higher Tire Pressure Urged Ford said Explorer owners should inflate their tires to 30 pounds per square inch, up from 26.
Stocks Finish Mixed The Nasdaq lost 25.11 points, to 3,803.76, and the S.& P. 500 slipped 0.33 point, to 1,448.72, but the Dow was up 81.85 points, to 10,847.37.
Auction Houses Settle Case Sotheby's and Christie's tentatively agreed to pay $512 million to settle claims of cheating customers.
Editorials: Gridlock at La Guardia; sleepovers and soft money; approval for RU-486; the wounded euro.
